title: FAA certification of UPS drone delivery business is a national first
text:
The company plans to “start moving that [model] across the country,” Bala Ganesh, head of the Advanced Technology Group at UPS, said in an interview. “There are a couple thousand of these hospital systems around the U.S., and we definitely see an immediate need for quite a few that we can start moving into.”

The company then wants to expand this “campus model,” he said, delivering urgently needed items over relatively short distances, to other industries.

“Today, we contract with third parties to run what we call ‘feeder flights,’ often to smaller cities and to remote areas,” said UPS spokesperson Kara Gerhardt Ross. “Larger drones may be able to manage that business more efficiently and cost effectively, and we are exploring that along with many other opportunities.”

Ganesh said UPS started a “full-court press” to secure the approval — a kind of airline certification — months ago, which paid off on Friday. The certification from the FAA additionally allows UPS to use drones that weigh more than 55 pounds with their cargo attached.

“Now, we are actually moving forward into a sustainable operating model,” Ganesh said. “We have no limits on the number of aircraft, the number of operators or the number of locations. So basically we have been cut loose to actually scale throughout the country.”

Earlier this year, the FAA granted a similar, but more limited, certification to Alphabet subsidiary Wing. Amazon Prime Air recently applied for an FAA exemption so it could make commercial drone deliveries.

Even with this certification, UPS needs an OK from the FAA before it flies a drone beyond visual line of sight, Ganesh noted. The FAA allowed it to do so for its first post-approval flight, making it the first “regular revenue-generating delivery” past the line of sight of the operator in the country. UPS has conducted a total of about 1,000 flights, for charge, at the Raleigh campus.
